intro: Sairocarpus subcordatus, commonly known as the narrow-lobed sedge, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with linear leaves and spike-like inflorescences. The plant typically grows in moist, often shaded environments such as wetlands and stream banks. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, arranged in dense clusters, and it produces triangular, three-sided seeds. Sairocarpus subcordatus is often found in temperate regions and is adapted to thrive in nutrient-rich, well-drained soils.
